The TFRP is a penalty against any sponsible person required to collect, account for, and pay over taxes held trust who willfully fails to perform any of these activities. The TFRP may imposed for: • Willful failure to collect tax, • Willful failure to account for and pay tax, or • Willful attempt in any manner to evade or defeat tax or the payment thereof. The TFRP may be asserted against any person “responsible” for collecting, accounting for, and paying over trust fund tax who:

Example: Pursuant to Howard v. United States, 711 F.2d 729 (5th Cir. 1983), more than one person may be held responsible, not just the most responsible person. Shepardizing reveals 19 cases in 5 circuits covering the issue.

Pursuant to Roth v. United States, 779 F.2d 1567 (11th Cir. 1987), in some cases a person may be liable for failure to pay over withheld funds to the United States, even if ordered by the corporation’s chief executive officer not to pay the taxes.

According to Thibodeau v. United States, 828 F.2d 1499 (11th Cir. 1987), the holding of corporate office, control over ﬁnancial affairs, the authority to disburse corporate funds, stock ownership, and the ability to hire and ﬁre employees are important factors to consider in determining

responsibility. Most TFRP cases involve officers of corporations. However, a responsible person may be one or more of the following: a. an officer or employee of a corporation b. a member or employee of a partnership c. a corporate director or shareholder d. a related controlling corporation e. employee of a sole proprietorship f. limited liability company (LLC) member, manager or employee g. a Payroll Service Provider (PSP) Note: The use of a third
